H0.text: Changes in the environment are the most likely cause of extinction to be found in the fossil record along with ichthyornis fossils, which are from a bird that lived over 65 million years ago, lived near the sea, hunted for fish over the water, and whose fossils were discovered in Kansas, many miles from the present‑day ocean.

H1.text: Diseases causing illness are the most likely cause of extinction to be found in the fossil record along with ichthyornis fossils, which lived over 65 million years ago near the sea, hunted fish over water, and whose fossils have been found in Kansas, many miles from the present‑day ocean.

H2.text: Changes in the weather are the most likely cause of extinction to be found in the fossil record alongside ichthyornis fossils, which lived over 65 million years ago near the sea, hunted fish over water, and whose fossils have been discovered in Kansas.

H3.text: Predator animals are the most likely cause of extinction that would be found in the fossil record along with ichthyornis fossils, a type of bird that lived over 65 million years ago, lived near the sea and hunted fish over the water, with fossils discovered in Kansas far from the present-day ocean.

A4.text: The loss of these seas greatly altered habitats, removing coastal plains that ten million years before had been host to diverse communities such as are found in rocks of the Dinosaur Park Formation.
